case_name: Madras Gymkhana Club Employees Union v. Gymkhana Club, Madras

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 572 of 1966 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 572 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Award dated September 2, 1964 of Industrial Tribunal, Madras in Industrial Dispute No. 19 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated September 2, 1964 of the Industrial Tribunal, Madras in industrial Dispute No. 19 of 1964.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal, Madras held by award dated September 2, 1964 that management of Gymkhana Club, Madras not liable to pay bonus to workmen for year 1962 as Club not an industry.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal, Madras by its award, September 2, 1964, has held that the management of the Gymkhana Club, Madras is number liable to pay bonus to its workmen for the year 1962 as the Club is number an industry.

facts.text: Madras Gymkhana Club Employees Union appeals to Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The Madras Gymkhana Club Employees Union number appeals to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: Madras Gymkhana Club is a members club and not a proprietary club.

anchor.surface_text: The Madras Gymkhana Club is admittedly a members club and number a proprietary club,

facts.text: On December 31, 1962, Gymkhana Club membership was about 1200 with 800 active members.

anchor.surface_text: On December 31, 1962 its membership was about 1200 with 800 active members.

facts.text: Object of the club is to provide venue for sports and games and facilities for recreation and entertainment.

anchor.surface_text: The object of the club is to provide a venue for sports and games and facilities for recreation and entertainment.

facts.text: Club maintains golf course, tennis courts, rugby and football grounds, arrangements for billiards, pingpong and other indoor games.

anchor.surface_text: For the former, it maintains a golf companyrse, tennis companyrts, rugby and football grounds and has made arrangement for billiards, pingpong and other indoor games.

facts.text: Club arranges dance, dinner and other parties and runs catering department providing food and refreshments generally and for special occasions.

anchor.surface_text: As part of the latter activities it arranges dance, dinner and other parties and runs a catering department, which provides and refreshments number only generally but also for dinners and parties on special occasions.

facts.text: Club employs six officers: a Secretary, a Superintendent and four Accountants and Cashiers.

anchor.surface_text: The club employs six officers  a Secretary, a Superintendent and four Accountants and Cashiers ,

facts.text: Club employs twenty clerks and a large number of peons, stewards, butlers, gate-attendants, etc.

anchor.surface_text: twenty clerks and a large number of peons, stewards, butlers, gate- attendants, etc.

facts.text: Catering department has separate managerial, clerical and other staff.

anchor.surface_text: Its catering department has a separate managerial, clerical and other staff.

facts.text: Club has altogether 194 employees.

anchor.surface_text: Altogether there are 194 employees.

facts.text: Affairs of the club managed by a Committee elected annually.

anchor.surface_text: The affairs of the club are managed by a Committee,elected annually.

facts.text: Two members of Committee work as Honorary Secretary and Honorary Treasurer.

anchor.surface_text: Two of the members of the Committee work as Hony. Secretary and Hony. Treasurer res- pectively.

facts.text: Resident members pay entrance fee of Rs. 300 and Rs. 20 per month subscription.

anchor.surface_text: The resident members pay an entrance fee of Rs. 300 and Rs. 20 per month as subscription.

facts.text: Garrison members and independent lady members do not pay entrance fee, subscription Rs. 10 per month.

anchor.surface_text: Garrison members and independent lady members do number pay any entrance fee and their subscription is Rs. 10 per month.

facts.text: Income and expenditure of club about four and a quarter lakh rupees.

anchor.surface_text: The income and expenditure of the club are of the order of four and a quarter lakh rupees,

facts.text: Movable and immovable properties worth several lakh rupees.

anchor.surface_text: its movable and immovable properties are worth several lakh rupees

facts.text: Wage bill between one and two lakh rupees.

anchor.surface_text: and its wage bill is between one and two lakh rupees.

facts.text: Appellant union contends that club must be treated as an industry under Industrial Disputes Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant union companytends that the decision of the Tribunal is number companyrect and that the club must be treated as an industry for the application of the Act.

facts.text: Tribunal concluded club not an industry after considering decisions of Supreme Court and High Courts.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal, after companysidering many decisions rendered by this Court and also by the High Courts in India, came to the companyclusion that the club was number an industry
Appeal by special leave from the Award dated September 2, 1964 of the Industrial Tribunal, Madras in industrial Dispute No. 19 of 1964.

The expression industrial dispute is defined by s. 2 k as follows industrial dispute means any dispute or difference between employers and employers or, between employers and workmen, or between workmen and workmen, which is connected with the employment or non-employment or the terms of employment or with the conditions of labour, of any person.

concepts.interpretation: Limits disputes to those connected with employment, non-employment, terms of employment or conditions of labour between specified parties.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: the chief executive officer of that authority Workman is defined by cl.  s  of the section and means any person  including an apprentice  employed in

anchor.surface_text: A Industry is defined in cl. j as follows- industry means any business, trade, undertaking, manufacture or calling of employers and includes any calling, service, employment, handicraft, or industrial occupation or avocation of workmen.

concepts.interpretation: First part denotes occupation of employers (business, trade, undertaking, manufacture, calling); second part extends to employees' activities; requires systematic activity for production/distribution of material goods or material services to community or part thereof analogous to trade/business; excludes members' clubs serving own pleasure.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: at the enterprise is financed by taxation and number by capital is companysidered irrelevant. In formulating these dicta the Court is obviously influe

anchor.surface_text: The word employer is defined by cl. g of the section as employer means- in relation to an industry carried on by or under the authority of any department of the Central Government or a State Government, the authority prescribed in this behalf, or where no authority is prescribed, the head of the department-, in relation to any industry carried on by or on behalf of a local authority, the chief executive officer of that authority

concepts.interpretation: Specifies authority as employer in government or local authority industries.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: he Army Act 1950, or the Air Force Act, 1950, or the Navy  Discipline  Act, 1934 or who is employed in the police service or as an officer or other em

anchor.surface_text: Workman is defined by cl. s of the section and means any person including an apprentice employed in any industry to do any skilled or unskilled manual supervisory, technical or clerical, work for hire or reward. whether the terms of employment be expressed or implied, and for the purpose of any proceeding under this Act in relation to an industrial dispute, includes any person who has been dismissed, discharged Or retrenched in connection with, or as a consequence of, that dispute, or whose dismissal, discharge or retrenchment has led to that dispute, but does not include any such person- who is subject to the Army Act 1950, or the Air Force Act, 1950, or the Navy Discipline Act, 1934 or who is employed in the police service or as an officer or other employee of a prison or who is employed mainly in a managerial or administrative capacity or who, being employed in a supervisor- capacity, draws wages exceeding five hundred rupees per mensem or exercises, either by the nature of the duties attached to the office or by reason of the powers vested in him, functions mainly of a managerial nature.

concepts.interpretation: Includes persons doing manual, supervisory, technical, clerical work for hire/reward; excludes managerial/administrative, high-paid supervisors, police, prison staff, armed forces personnel.

anchor.surface_text: that a municipal undertaking of the nature we have under consideration is an industry within the meaning of the word in S. 2 j of the Industrial Disputes Act and that the expression industrial dispute in that Act includes disputes between the municipality and their employees in branches of work that can be regarded as analogous to the carrying on of a trade or business.

concepts.interpretation: Activity must be analogous to carrying on of trade or business involving employer-employee cooperation for material goods/services.

issues.text: whether the respondent club can be said to be an industry for the application of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947

anchor.surface_text: The question in this appeal is whether the respondent club can be said to be an industry for the application of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947. The Tribunal, after considering many decisions rendered by this Court and also by the High Courts in India, came to the conclusion that the club was not an industry and the claim for bonus on behalf of its employees was therefore unsustainable.

issues.text: whether the club comes within the definition of industry as given in the Industrial Disputes Act

anchor.surface_text: As we are concerned primarily with the question whether the club comes within the definition of industry as given in the Industrial Disputes Act, we may begin by reading that definition and other provisions which have a bearing upon the question. The Industrial Disputes Act was passed to make provision for the investigation and settlement of industrial disputes and for certain other purposes appearing in the Act.

issues.text: whether the Madras Gymkhana Club fulfills the tests laid down by this Court

anchor.surface_text: This ends discussion of what is an industry. We are now in a position to consider whether the Madras Gymkhana Club fulfills the tests laid down by this Court and accepted here by us. in support of the claim on behalf of the Employees Union, our attention was drawn to two decisions of the Calcutta High Court relating to the Bengal Club Ltd.

the running of clubs is not the calling of the members or its managing committee. The only question is, is it an undertaking? Here the appearances are somewhat against the club. It is not of any consequence that there is no profit motive because that is considered immaterial. It is also true that the affairs of the club are, organised in the way business is organised.

holdings.text: The Madras Gymkhana Club is not an industry within the meaning of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied tests from prior Supreme Court cases to facts of members' club: self-serving for members' pleasure, not systematic production/distribution of material goods/services to community analogous to trade/business.

holdings.text: An activity is an industry if it is an undertaking analogous to the carrying on of a trade or business.

anchor.surface_text: that a municipal undertaking of the nature we have under consideration is an industry within the meaning of the word in S. 2 j of the Industrial Disputes Act and that the expression industrial dispute in that Act includes disputes between the municipality and their employees in branches of work that can be regarded as analogous to the carrying on of a trade or business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Synthesized from prior cases like Banerjee, Baroda Borough; undertaking takes color from business/trade; extends to non-profit but requires analogy to trade.

holdings.text: Profit motive is not essential for an activity to be an industry.

anchor.surface_text: It is not of any consequence that there is no profit motive because that is considered immaterial.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Confirmed from precedents like Hospital Mazdoor Sabha; irrelevant whether financed by capital, taxation, or fares.

holdings.text: The size, scale, organization, or extent of activities does not determine if an activity is an industry; essential character matters.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot go by the size of the club or the largeness of its membership or the number or extent of there activities. We have to consider the essential character of the Club activity

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejected petitioner's emphasis on club's large scale, staff, facilities; focused on whether analogous to trade serving community vs. self-serving.

holdings.text: A members' club provides services for its own members' pleasure and consumption, not material services to the community, hence not an industry.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Club identified with members; no independent existence; services not sold to outsiders as of right; analogous to domestic/personal service exclusion.

holdings.text: Admission of guests to a members' club does not alter its character as a self-serving institution.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Guests enter only via members; privileges not purchasable; stopping guests changes nothing essential.

holdings.text: The extension of 'undertaking' to cover municipal activities in Corporation of Nagpur case contradicted earlier precedents and was unfortunate.

anchor.surface_text: whether and to what extent the Corporation of Nagpur was an industry under the C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947 That Act included a definition of industry which was different. ... Its extension in the Corporation case was unfortunate and contradicted the earlier cases.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Nagpur case used different statute definition; overextended 'undertaking' beyond analogy to trade/business from Banerjee/Baroda.

holdings.text: Learned professions like solicitors are not industry as they depend on personal qualifications without direct/essential nexus from employees.

anchor.surface_text: the association of capital and labour must be direct and essential. The service of a solicitor was regarded as individual depending upon his personal qualifications and ability, to which the employees did not contribute directly or essentially.

holdings.reasoning_summary: From Meher case; employer's occupation not satisfying first part of definition.
